Name: Leucine Auxotrophic Marker (leu)
Summarized Function: The leucine auxotrophic marker gene (leu) enables selection for transformed cells that lack the ability to synthesize leucine, requiring the presence of leucine in the growth medium.
Description: The leu gene, derived from the leucine biosynthetic pathway, is used to complement leucine auxotrophy in host cells that cannot synthesize leucine. In plasmid systems, the leu gene provides a means of selecting for cells that have taken up the plasmid, as these cells can synthesize leucine and grow in its absence. Host strains deficient in the leu gene require external leucine to survive, which is supplied by the plasmid containing the functional leu gene. This system is commonly used in yeast and certain bacterial plasmids for selection and maintenance.
Notes: Using leucine auxotrophic markers is particularly useful in systems where antibiotic selection is not applicable. This marker ensures that only cells containing the plasmid with the leu gene can grow in media lacking leucine. This method is commonly employed in yeast plasmid systems for maintaining plasmid stability and ensuring successful transformation.
